comments.commentBody: Let's see...first they got bail out money that covered all their bad mortgages. Then they double dipped by foreclosing on them and they're collecting monthly mortgage payments from taxpayers whose money was stolen and given to them. Now they're charging fees on debit cards. Are they partners with pharmaceutical companies or insurance companies or big oil? It seems they all have the same agenda, and they all have license to rip us off.

About 15 years ago when PNC Bank was a smaller regional bank, they raised their fees to an exorbitant level.  Within a year they had lost so many customers in Pittsburgh, their home base, they removed the fees and apologized to the community.  It was a long time before they recovered from this fiasco.  I hope PNC remembers this painful lesson.

If banks start adding a debit card fee you can bet I'll quit using a debit card. Banks have very long sticky fingers. They want a cut of all transactions. I can implement changes to keep them out of my pocket.
This is so outrageous that I've decided to pay a fee to go to NYTimes.com to post a comment.

Please, if you have an account with BoA or other big national banks, don't switch to a local, fee-free bank or credit union!  Doing so will cause the big banks to lose money.  And since the profits of big banks and million-dollar executive salaries are critical to the functioning of our modern society, any reduction of profit will require another taxpayer bailout.  So please, support the big banks by paying their fees.  It's your patriotic duty.
Regions Bank is charging $4 a month for debit card usage, beginning October 1st.
I also bank with B of A. And, if I see these charges assessed, I will move my business elsewhere.

Do I like this? No. Will I close all of my accounts? No. Just going to put everything on my credit card and pay it off in full every month. That's what I've always done. I'd suggest everyone else do the same... but we all know most Americans are carrying the maximum balance and making the minimum payment on their cards. You're all just as bad as the banks.
Time to move on to the credit union. Thank you Congress for your out-of-touch legislation...once again, another well intentioned law that does nothing to help the people.
THat is awesome.  If they could also list price relative to what has represented to the seller upfront it would be perfect.  Well done guys.

Google "credit union" and the city where you live, and you'll find credit unions, some of which you are eligible for membership.

Even though most credit unions are local, you'll find that you can use ATMs and "service centers" FREE all across the country. Free.

Plenty of community banks and credit unions out there that are friendly, don't indulge in nickel-and-diming, offer decent interest on free checking accounts etc. Yet even this latest dip into customer pockets won't convince millions of Americans to switch from Glominoid Bank to a saner alternative. I guess all that advertising really does work.....

What's this? Banks dispersing the risk from people who can't pay attention to their balance to anyone?

Thank you Obama.

This doesn't sound familiar at all.

You make the right sound better every day, which is pretty scary if you ask me.
One more example of regulators being way behind the pitch. Why, I wonder, do so many who bemoan the ineffectiveness of regulation want still more of it? A fee to access one's own cash, indeed.

Vermonter, it's even worse than you think it is. Banks don't pay "almost nothing" for the money that they lend - they pay exactly nothing. Read about fractional reserve banking. ( http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fractional_reserve_banking ) Banks lend money that they created out of thin air!

Now NoA is faced with a potential $50 billion lawsuit ofr nvestor fraud for buying Merrill Lynch without giving all the details THEY KNEW ABOUT the state of the thundering herd. Are those fees going to cover that loss or the change in transation fees? It is time to bring those too big to fail out of the game of no politician is too big that our lobbyists can't purchase a Congress. Those CEOs should have been the first one to experience what unemployment means without the golden parachute that cronnies gave them.

This country needs to end its dependence on monies stolen from its citizens. In fact, the banks have been stealing so much money from people that there is no more money to steal... consequently, we find our country in the sad shape that it is in today.

And, is running out of money to steal a wake-up call to big banks? No.
Is the nearly 1 TRILLION dollars they received from our corrupt (or is it simply 'idiotic') government enough for them? no, it doesn't appear so.

Does it matter to our governemnt that we borrow 1 TRILLION dollars of money that this country does not actually have (is this Chinese money?), indebting our citizens for generations to come for no good reason, other than to line the pockets of big business and banking executives... are new jobs and industries being created out of all this... NO, it doesn't appear so.

Are we ever going to get back this country?

Have we already allowed this country to be sold off... have we been sold out by big business and our government?

I ask you, what do you call it when governemnt and big business are one and the same? And, what do you call it when this combined government and big buisness controls citizens lives (especially, those in debt) to the extent that they do today? What would you call it tomorrow?

Freedom? Democracy? I think not.
Won't be the first time I changed banks because they got greedy.

I wonder how long it will take all these new fees to disappear once the big banks figure out everyone is switching to credit unions. I did earlier this year and am now enjoying something I thought had disappeared: Interest!

I just got a letter today form Citybank telling me I have to either maintain a $6000 balance or pay $15/month for my checking account, and also I won't be getting mileage anymore for using my bank card. So I'm not sure what the reference in the article to not charging is all about.

But what's really going on is paper thin. They want Dodd-Frank to be repealed.

There are LOTS of people who use pre-paid debit cards, some with already exorbitant fees ($.90 per transaction, for example).  Some also use pre-paid debit cards to receive government benefits and the like.  I imagine the latter will be spared, but what about the former?  We're talking already poor people here, who can't bank 'traditionally' and refill their cards at check-cashing places.  I certainly hope we (I'm one) won't also get hit by excella, netspend and Rush (for example) when we are least able to afford such fees!

poor banks,can't gouge us with the usual fees,so they invent new ones! want to use your debit card? that will be $5.00 please. my bank changed its whole fee structure,which meant I either pay it or have to contact the source of my checks and open another account for a direct deposit,which will save me a fee. people will get fed up with these fees and go elsewhere
.except all the banks are going to start doing this! Stick it to the little guy whenever possible. unless you have a lot of money in the bank,then they won't charge you.

[[13. Joseph New York September 29th, 2011 9:38 pm Thank you, President Obama. When will you leftists learn: you can't dictate to businesses how they are to make their money. When you do, you distort the market, and create perverse results, like these customer debit card fees.]]

You really should look at what's actually in the credit card reform act. The old ways of the credit card companies were obscene. The changes included:

Banning universal default and double-cycle billing.

Prohibiting over-limit fees unless consumers agree to allow transactions that exceed their credit limits to go through rather than be denied.

Fees for late payments, over-limit charges or other penalty fees must be reasonable and related to the violation.

Extending the life of gift cards and gift certificates so that they cannot expire within five years of activation. Banning dormancy or inactivity fees on gift cards unless there has been no activity in a 12-month period.

Requiring that card issuers disclose how long it would take to pay off credit card balances if cardholders make only minimum payments each month and how much users would have to pay each month if they want to pay off their balances in 36 months.

How is it that we pay no fees to use checks, which are inherently more costly for the banks to process, yet we must pay fees for debit cards which simply electronically transfer money from one account to the other?
Because banks are for profit institutions designed to make money for the investors, we the clients are the source of the profits ... fortunately we have options, in Credit Unions the profits are returned to the clients in services and better loan rates.

Banks had a choice:side with their customers who actually have money in the bank, or with the Wall Street Analysts who demand unrealistic rates or return.  The Banks chose Wall Street.  I will choose a local bank or credit union. So long too big to fail. If you don't have my interests at heart, I don't have yours.
